hints.content: Start by understanding the problem requirements. You need to make three strings equal by deleting characters from the end of the strings. Remember, you cannot completely empty any string.
Think about the final state you want to achieve. All three strings should end with the same substring. What might that substring look like?
Consider how you can find the longest common suffix of the three strings. This will help you determine how many characters you need to delete from each string.
To find the longest common suffix, you can compare the strings from the end towards the beginning. Keep track of how many characters match.
If the longest common suffix has a length of 'k', then each string must be reduced to this length. Calculate how many characters need to be deleted from each string.
Make sure to handle cases where the strings differ at the very start. If the first characters of the strings are different, it's impossible to make them equal.
When calculating the number of deletions, remember that the strings must not be completely empty. Ensure that after deletions, each string has at least one character left.
If you find that one or more strings cannot be reduced to match the others without becoming empty, return -1 immediately.
Consider edge cases such as when all strings are already equal or when they have only one character in common. How would your logic handle these cases?
Finally, once you have the lengths of the strings and the common suffix, compute the total deletions needed: total deletions = (length of s1 - k) + (length of s2 - k) + (length of s3 - k).

questionNotes: s1, s2, and s3 consist only of lowercase English letters.
You cannot completely empty any string; each must have at least one character left.
If it's impossible to make the strings equal, return -1.
